issues.description: The problem statement instructs students to call personRepository.save(..) with a boolean 'force' flag set to true (i.e., a save method that accepts a boolean). However, both the template and the solution use the standard Spring Data JPA JpaRepository.save(Person) method which does not accept such a boolean parameter. This mismatch will confuse students: they may try to call personRepository.save(person, true) (as described) but no such method exists in the provided repository interface, causing compilation errors or blocking implementation.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the problem statement with the actual repository API. Either (a) remove the mention of a 'force' boolean parameter and instruct students to call personRepository.save(person) (preferred), or (b) if the boolean flag is required pedagogically, add an appropriate save(Person, boolean) method to the PersonRepository interface (and update template/solution implementations/tests accordingly). The simplest and least disruptive fix is to update the problem statement to use the standard save(person) call.

issues.description: The problem statement requires calling a repository save method that accepts a boolean 'force' flag ("The save method accepts a boolean flag 'force' which you must set to true"), but both the template and solution code use the standard JpaRepository save(Person) method and do not provide any save(Person, boolean) overload. This mismatch between the described API and the provided code will confuse students: they may search for or attempt to call save(person, true) while the repository only exposes save(person).
issues.suggested_fix: Align the problem statement and code. Either (A) remove the reference to a boolean 'force' parameter in the problem statement and instruct students to call the standard personRepository.save(person) (recommended, since JpaRepository defines save(Person)), or (B) if a 'force' flag is required by the exercise intent, add a clearly defined custom repository method (for example: PersonRepository.save(Person person, boolean force) or a domain-specific method like saveWithForce(Person person, boolean force)) to the template repository and update the solution and service implementations accordingly so the API and description match.
